basics.name: Eilish McMaster
basics.summary: I'm an early career researcher working in the field of ecological genomics. I have extensive experience working with environmental metagenomic data, and more recently I've started working on conservation population genomics with plant genomes.

work.company: NSW Department of Planning and Environment
work.summary: In my role at the Research Centre for Ecosystem Resilience (ReCER) I conduct population genomics analyses on endangered plant species to inform conservation action. These analyses utilise whole genome SNP data and include taxonomic clarification, diversity assessment, gene flow and admixture detection, kinship analyses, and genetic optimisation of translocation populations. These projects are primarily associated with species undergoing management by the Saving our Species initiative (SoS) of the NSW government.

At the Centre for Microbiome Research (CMR) I worked on lab based and bioinformatics projects investigating the ecology of the human gut, coral, and permafrost microbiomes. In the wet lab I designed and optimised protocols for novel techniques, conducted molecular and microscopy experiments, and worked with biosecurity materials. I also analysed metagenomic sequence data and contributed to paper and grant writing.

At the University of Queensland I tutored third year bachelors subjects parasitology, biochemistry, and human genetics. This involved both lab based and online teaching. I was awarded top tutor based on student reviews in 2020.

In 2020 I undertook an honours research project at the Australian Centre for Ecogenomics (ACE) on the microbial community of thawing permafrost with a specific focus on bacteria-bacteria symbiosis. This encompassed genome reconstruction from metagenomic data, metabolic analysis from reconstructed genomes, co-phylogeny analysis, and machine learning prediction.

From 2018 to 2020 I worked as a research assistant in Professor Margaret Mayfield’s lab, which focusses on the community ecology of Western Australian native plants. My work involved experimental design and setup, using plant growth chambers, and data collection, and analysis.

In 2019 I undertook an independent research project in Associate Professor Paul Dennis’ lab on the interactions of the banana plant microbiome and the fungal pathogen Fusarium oxysporum. I used various fungal and bacterial culturing techniques and was able to identify several isolates from the banana microbiome that had moderate inhibitory effects on F. oxysporum.

Professor Clifton’s lab has a focus on foetal development and the impact of nicotine, alcohol, and glucocorticosteroids on the mRNA expression of the foetus and placenta. In this lab I conducted DNA extraction and amplification on cell culture and tissue samples, as well as qPCR, and maintenance and treatment of various placental cell lines.

genome assembly, binning, and quality checking

references.name: Phil Hugenholtz
references.reference: Despite the disruptions due to the COVID-19 shutdown, Eilish persisted in her research and showed great adaptability; overnight her project changed from largely wet-lab to entirely computational, which she took in her stride. Within the first five months she had completed the investigations that were planned to take a year. Not only did she perform well in her own work, but also willingly offered her time to help others with their projects when she was able. This dedication to her work coupled with her ability to learn independently has made her an excellent student to supervise.
